Award.AwardTitle: GeoScholars at University of West Florida

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of West Florida Geoscience Scholars program will investigate the effect of a multidisciplinary research cohort on student success and pursuit of graduate studies and careers in STEM and the geosciences. Undergraduate research in the geosciences will be used as a mechanism for enhancing the perception of multidisciplinary collaborative research and as a focal point for the development of "soft" skills, such as verbal and written communication, critical to professional success. A research cohort model will be used. This model will be built around multidisciplinary research projects founded in the earth sciences and employing regular professional skills-development activities to encourage post-baccalaureate interest in the geosciences. Faculty mentors and research students from across the STEM disciplines will be engaged in the project, ensuring students will have opportunities to participate in undergraduate research in their chosen field of study, while also observing the application of their field of study to the geosciences.

This project will pilot and assess the impact of a multidisciplinary research cohort intended to increase the number of students prepared to enter the geoscience workforce or continue on to graduate programs in the geosciences. The project will contribute to the creation of knowledge related to the impact of multidisciplinary research cohorts on student success and engagement in STEM graduate studies and careers, both within the geosciences and in the broader STEM community. This project will research how multidisciplinary cohorts impact student success and retention, decisions to continue in a geoscience graduate program, and preparation for the workforce. A professional skills seminar course will be introduced to help students develop verbal and written communication skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of West Florida (UWF) GeoScholars project was designed to provide teams of undergraduate research students with both technical and professional development training as part of collaborative multidisciplinary research projects.  The goal of this project was to enhance Earth Science-based interdisciplinary research as a mechanism for building cross-disciplinary expertise in undergraduate students that would benefit their academic and professional success during, and after, their undergraduate careers. 

Specifically, we worked with UWF faculty to create a network of interdisciplinary teams made up of students and faculty who were working together to complete scientific research projects that were grounded in Earth Science, but required expertise from other disciplines, including Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Electrical and Computer Engineering, and Mathematics and Statistics.  Research topics included:

  • Using large data sets and computer models to assess the causes of droughts in the southeastern USA
  • Detecting sediment/soil contaminants (DDT and PAHs)
  • Building a small-scale air quality detector for assessing indoor and outdoor environmental air quality
  • Comparing and contrasting drones to assess coastal water quality and dune migration
  • Performing a walkability study to plan locations for electric vehicle charging stations
  • Assessing distribution and public knowledge of microplastic contamination
  • Assessing distribution and public knowledge of flesh-eating bacteria in a Gulf Coast estuary

These research teams worked together for a minimum of one year to plan and execute multidisciplinary research for presentation at University, regional, and international meetings.  Undergraduate students served as the lead presenters for all research presentations.

The UWF GeoScholars project involved integrated professional development training for all participating students to ensure that students developed non-technical skills that would benefit their consisting of guest presentations from national-level interdisciplinary researchers; virtual group discussions with faculty from PhD programs about applying to graduate school; training on verbal and written communication skills; preparing graduate school application letters; preparing applications for private-sector employment; and question and answer sessions with geoscience employers.

We also invested in creating interest in, and opportunity for, interdisciplinary learning concepts in a variety of undergraduate courses:  non-Earth Science faculty were hired as curricular fellows to design instructional content (examples, laboratory experiments, test problems, etc.) that used Earth Science examples to teach content in Chemistry, Physics, and Elementary Statistics.

The UWF GeoScholars program has created collaborative research partnerships between UWF faculty that will persist after the completion of this project.  Undergraduate student participants have reported improved expertise in technical (research) and professional skills, as well as improved confidence in these areas.  That is, they reported that the GeoScholars program contributed to their preparation to enter graduate school or the workforce.
